Since we can reject now and potentially still receive Student_C later if they remain unmatched (they strongly prefer us), the strategic move is to reject to keep the seat available for higher-priority candidates.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest and for the thoughtful question.

Because we have only one seat, the condition under which we would extend an offer to a lower-priority candidate is: (1) we have strong reason to believe that our higher-priority students (those ranked above you) have secured placements elsewhere and are unlikely to apply to School_B in the remaining rounds, or (2) we reach a late stage of the process where it becomes impractical to keep the seat open any longer.

Practically, we are planning to reassess this in the later rounds (around the final third of the process). If at that point the higher-priority candidates have not approached us and the market appears settled, we would begin considering remaining interested students. If/when we reach that point, you are welcome to submit a formal [APPLY] immediately and we will review promptly.

Sincerely,
School_B Admissions

As of Round 10, our approach has not changed: we are still keeping our single remaining seat open while we monitor whether any higher-priority candidates may become available and choose to apply to School_B in upcoming rounds.
